Title: DEVELOPMENT GRANT PROGRAM EVALUATION, AFGHANISTAN (2/25/63)

Abstract: In-depth analysis and case history up to 1/10/63 of 1954-initiated National Agric Dvlp Research Tech Assistance Project in Afghanistan. Proj designed to improve the quality/quantity of agric production & exportable crops through research programs, testing, & demonstrations. With assistance of Univ of Wyoming (UWy) contract and direct-hire technicians/advisors and an FAO technician, proj accomplishments thus far include six fully operational agronomic research stations; a model dairy and model poultry farm; over 100,000 fruit trees distributed & budded; annual distribution of 400,000 plants to farmers; development of high-yield varieties of cotton, sugar beets, and other crops; and testing of hundreds of varieties of agronomic crops.  Per acre production has increased seven times in certain cases and dvlp of rust-resistant wheat assures more uniform yields in this basic crop. Hampshire Red roosters introduced by the proj have become the dominant poultry breed. While proj exceeded original goals in some respects, it failed to reach many goals, hampered in large part by the Afghan Govt's incapacity in supply of personnel, land & funding resources.  Of particular consequence has been a failure to institutionalize proj outputs. Ministry of Agric (MOA) officials have not demonstrated sufficient interest in proj.  American technicians have superseded advisory roles to achieve proj results.  The number of Ministry officials assigned to proj has been reduced.  Of 12 BS partic trainees, only 2 remain directly associated with MOA component of proj.  USAID faulted for not insisting on joint coordination & planning. Proj results remain for most part unpublished. In marked contrast, full senior-level Afghan participation has helped shape steady progress & usable results in Helmand Valley Authority component of proj:  2 research stations are in operation and 2 partic trainees now head the agronomy & livestock programs. USAID has decided to phase out the UWy contract and retain a direct-hire staff equivalent to the number of Afghans assigned, making meaningful future progress dependent on Afghan commitment.

Title: TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE PROJECT CASE HISTORY : NATIONAL AGRICULTURAL DEVELOPMENT RESEARCH

Abstract: This report, one 23 country studies conducted as part of a worldwide survey, reviews A.I.D.'s participant training program in the Sudan since its inception in 1958.  The study was based on oral interviews with 100 returned participants, 40 supervisors, and 10 U.S. technicians; areas covered included the effectiveness of the training and suggestions for its improvement. Recommmendations are in the areas of orientation, support services, and utilization of training.  (Author abstract, modified)

Title: Evaluation study of the Agency for International Development participant training program in Sudan

Abstract: The purpose of this study was to examine past experiences in order to make future participant training programs pay greater dividends in the rapid development of economic growth in Taiwan. The study involved oral interviews with returned participants, supervisors, and U.S. technicians. A series of recommendations are included on various aspects of the participant training program, some of which are too general and political to be of utility to planners and policy makers. However, there are specific suggestions in the areas of training design, selection, pre-departure preparation, English language, and follow-up. (Author abstract)
Title: Technical training - Republic of China : an evaluation, 1951-1963

Abstract: This report is one of twenty-three country studies conducted as part of the worldwide survey of returned participants in accordance with AID/W instructions and guidelines contained in ICATO Circular A-175, November 1959. The major purpose of this global effort was to obtain an overview of how the participant training program was progressing to ascertain ways in which future training might be more effective at the country, AID/W, and training institution levels. The interview sample included 524 returned Korean participants, 305 supervisors, and 52 U.S. technicians. The study contains an excellent set of recommendations which are principally in the areas of training design, location of training, selection, pre-departure preparation, English language, support services, follow-up, and utilization. (Author abstract)
Title: Evaluation survey of the Korea/US participant training program

Abstract: This report is one of twenty-three country studies conducted as part of A.I.D.'s worldwide survey of participant training in accordance with AID/W instructions and guidelines contained in ICATO Circular A-175, November 1959.  The major purpose of this global effort was to obtain an overview of how the participant training program was progressing to ascertain ways in which future training might be more effective at the country, AID/W, and training institution levels.  The findings for the Ecuador study are based on structured oral interviews with 391 returned participants, 149 supervisors, and 31 U.S. technicians concerning the training program.  No recommendations are made per se, but several are suggested or implied in the areas of training design and support services.  (Author abstract)
Inst_Author: 004167 - Research Tabulating Corp.|004168 - Rome Arnold and Co.
Title: Evaluation study of the Agency for International Development participant training program in Ecuador

Abstract: This report, one of 23 country studies conducted as part of a world-wide survey, reviews A.I.D.'s participant training program in Brazil. The study was based on oral interviews of 538 returned participants, 306 supervisors, and 48 U.S. technicians. Recommendations, which are general in nature, cover training design, location of training, selection, placement, pre-departure preparation, English language, support services, follow-up, and professional development. (Author abstract, modified)
Title: Report on evaluation survey of participant training

Abstract: This report, one of 23 country studies conducted as part of a world-wide survey, reviews A.I.D.'s participant training program in Egypt 1952 and 1962.  The report was based on oral interviews of 309 of 445 returned Egyptian participants and 55 supervisors. Although no recommendations were made in this study, the findings suggest that the training period be extended (85% of programs were for less than one year) and that participants be followed up after return.  (Author abstract, modified)

Title: Evaluation survey of the United Arab Republic - United States participant training program, 1952-1962

Abstract: This report provides descriptive data and insight into the participant training program in eight selected countries.  The study includes data collected from an earlier survey in 20 countries of exchanges sponsored by the U.S. Department of State. While no specific recommendations are made, the report provides an interesting description of returned participants' views and attitudes about their U.S. training experience.  (Participant training abstract)

Abstract: This report, one of 23 country studies conducted as part of a worldwide survey, reviews A.I.D.'s participant training program in Thailand from 1951 to 1960.  Personal interviews were held with a sample of returned Thai participants, their immediate supervisors, and the U.S. technicians concerned with the projects under which training was sponsored.  Recommendations in the areas of training design, selection, pre-departure preparation, follow-up, and professional development are included. (Author abstract, modified)
